body.p:
Hon B. Magoffin
Governor of Kentucky

Your Excellency has heretofore, we understand had your attention called to the pardon of William Brookover, & we deem it unnecessary to say any thing in regard to the facts of the case, & will only refer you to the record of the case on file in the Clerk's office of the Court of Appeal, at Frankfort, We beleive that this case is one calling for the exercise of executive clemancy, & that you will agree with us, when you examine into the case as developed in this record --

Brookover has been prosecuted with unrelenting fury & rancor. No one can be injured by his pardon, The public will sustain no wrong thereby -- His wife, who is a worthy woman, & who seems devotedly attached to him, will have a mountain weight removed from her mind.

We would suggest that the par-
don may be conditional, & void upon his return to Kentucky.
We believe this is a strong case for the exercise of clemency -- and mercy, & hope it may accord with your views to grant the pardon as above indicated

Geo. W. Sulser
Thos J. Throop
R. H. Stanton
Jno,, B, Poynty
Lewis Collins
Jno R. Clarke
Hiram Bassett
Nelson Whitaker
Jno D Taylor
Frances T. Hord
Saml W. Owens
Jas P. Poynty

I am well acquainted with Brookover & have had a great many dealings with him, before this transaction for which he was indicted & found guilty & I have always found him honest & correct. Public opinion seemed to be against him in this trial, he was prosecuted with an unrelenting fury, & great pains taken to poison the public mind against ^him^ but I have every reason to believe him innocent ^or great doubts in regard to his guilt^ & that your Excellency ought to pardon him, if not for his own sake for the sake of his wife, who is a truly
worthy woman, & for the sake of his children
